view.name: Major Contract Awards
view.description:
This set of contract awards includes data on commitments against contracts that were reviewed by the Bank before they were awarded (prior-reviewed Bank-funded contracts) under IDA/IBRD investment projects and related Trust Funds. This dataset does not list all contracts awarded by the Bank, and should be viewed only as a guide to determine the distribution of major contract commitments among the Bank's member countries. "Supplier Country" represents place of supplier registration, which may or not be the supplier's actual country of origin. Information does not include awards to subcontractors nor account for cofinancing. The Procurement Policy and Services Group does not guarantee the data included in this publication and accepts no responsibility whatsoever for any consequences of its use.  The World Bank complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions.

Visit Bank’s Procurement page for more information: http://go.worldbank.org/9KQZWXNOI0

view.name: IBRD Statement of Loans - Latest Available Snapshot
view.description: The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) loans are public and publicly guaranteed debt extended by the World Bank Group. IBRD loans are made to, or guaranteed by, countries that are members of IBRD. IBRD may also make loans to IFC. IBRD lends at market rates. Data are in U.S. dollars calculated using historical rates. This dataset contains the latest available snapshot of the Statement of Loans. The World Bank complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions.

columns.name: End of Period
columns.description: End of Period Date represents the date as of which balances are shown in the report.

columns.name: Loan Number
columns.description: For IBRD loans and IDA credits or grants a loan number consists of the organization prefix (IBRD/IDA) and a five-character label that uniquely identifies the loan within the organization.  In IDA, all grant labels start with the letter ‘H’.

columns.name: Region

columns.description: The currency in which a borrower’s loan, credit or grant is denominated.

columns.name: Project Name
columns.description: Short descriptive project name.

columns.name: Original Principal Amount
columns.description: The original US dollar amount of the loan that is committed and approved.

columns.name: Cancelled Amount
columns.description: The portion of the undisbursed balance which has been cancelled (i.e. no longer available for future disbursement).  Cancellations include terminations (where approved loan agreements were never signed).

columns.name: Undisbursed Amount
columns.description: The amount of a loan commitment that is still available to be drawn down. These currency amounts have been converted to US dollars at the exchange rates applicable at the End of Period date.

columns.name: Disbursed Amount
columns.description: The amount that has been disbursed from a loan commitment in equivalent US dollars calculated at the exchange rate on the value date of the individual disbursements.

columns.name: Repaid to IBRD
columns.description: Total principal amounts paid or prepaid to IBRD in US dollars, calculated at the exchange rate on the value date of the individual repayments.

columns.name: Due to IBRD
columns.description: Where the exchange adjustment is shown separately, this is the amount disbursed and outstanding expressed as a stock of debt in historical US Dollars.   Otherwise, this is the amount due and outstanding as of the End of Period date.

columns.name: Exchange Adjustment
columns.description: The increase (decrease) in value of disbursed and outstanding amount due to exchange rate fluctuations.  This amount added to “Due to IBRD” yields “Borrower’s Obligation; includes exchange adjustments on the amounts Due to 3rd parties.

columns.name: Borrower's Obligation
columns.description:
The Borrower Obligation is the outstanding balance for the loan as of the end of period date in US dollars equivalent. 

The Borrower's Obligation includes the amounts outstanding Due to 3rd parties.

columns.description: Portion of loan sold to a third party.

columns.name: Repaid 3rd Party
columns.description: Amount repaid to a third party.

columns.name: Due 3rd Party
columns.description: Amount due to a third party.

columns.name: Loans Held
columns.description: The sum of the disbursed and outstanding amounts (net of repayments, i.e.  Due to IBRD) plus undisbursed available amounts.

columns.name: First Repayment Date
columns.description: The date on which principal repayment starts.

columns.name: Last Repayment Date
columns.description: The date specified in the loan/credit agreement (amended for any partial prepayments) on which the last principal installment must be repaid by the Borrower.

columns.name: Agreement Signing Date
columns.description: The date the borrower and the Bank sign the loan agreement.

columns.name: Board Approval Date
columns.description: The date the World Bank approves the loan.

columns.name: Effective Date (Most Recent)
columns.description: The date on which a legal agreement becomes effective, or is expected to become effective.

columns.name: Closed Date (Most Recent)
columns.description: The date specified in the legal agreement (or extension) after which the Bank may, by notice to the borrower, terminate the right to make withdrawals from the loan account.

columns.name: Last Disbursement Date
columns.description: The date on which the last disbursement was made (prior to the end of period date).

view.name: IDA Statement of Credits and Grants  - Latest Available Snapshot
view.description:
The International Development Association (IDA) credits are public and publicly guaranteed debt extended by the World Bank Group. IDA provides development credits, grants and guarantees to its recipient member countries to help meet their development needs. Credits from IDA are at concessional rates. Data are in U.S. dollars calculated using historical rates. This dataset contains the latest available snapshot of the IDA Statement of Credits and Grants. The World Bank complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank
transactions.

view.name: Corporate Procurement Contract Awards
view.description: This set of data includes listings of large value contracts awards that were executed by the World Bank Group, pursuant to its Corporate Procurement Policies and Procedures. The listing includes both fixed price an indefinite delivery / indefinite quantity (IDIQ) contracts with an estimated value above US$250,000.  The value for Fixed Price contracts is disclosed at the award value.  The value for IDIQ contracts is not disclosed and is based on an estimate of possible value which is $250,000 or greater. This data set does not list all contracts awarded by the World Bank Group, and should be viewed only as a guide to determine the distribution of major contract commitments made by the World Bank Group. "Supplier Country" represents place of supplier registration in the World Bank's Vendor Database, which may or not be the supplier's actual country of origin. Please note that the Corporate Procurement Unit is responsible for ensuring that procurement awards are consistent with procurement policies and procedures, while business units are accountable for the business need, expenditure policy, procurement specification and supplier selection. The information provided is believed to be accurate; however the World Bank Group is not responsible should the data be incorrect, incomplete or if data is omitted. Learn more about Corporate Procurement at http://go.worldbank.org/6PC0FICAE0 .

view.name: IBRD Subscriptions and Voting Power of Member Countries
view.description:
Member countries are allocated votes at the time of membership and subsequently for additional subscriptions to capital. Votes are allocated differently in each organization.

Each member receives votes consisting of share votes (one vote for each share of the Bank's capital stock held by the member) plus basic votes (calculated so that the sum of all basic votes is equal to 5.55 percent of the sum of basic votes and share votes for all members).

Latest information about voting power is available at http://www.worldbank.org/en/about/leadership/votingpowers

view.name: Paid In Contributions to IBRD/IDA/IFC Trust Funds based on FY of Receipt
view.description:
A Recipient-executed Grant is a Trust Fund Grant that is provided to a third party under a grant agreement, and for which the Bank plays an operational role - i.e., the Bank normally appraises and supervises activities financed by these funds. This dataset provides data on the amount of grant funds committed in the course of a fiscal year and payments made out of a Trust Fund account to eligible recipients, in accordance with the legal agreements. In fulfilling its responsibilities, the World Bank as Trustee complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions. All definitions should be regarded at present as provisional and not final, and are subject to revision at any time. 
Data is provided at the individual Trust Fund level and is updated as of 04/02/2015. No further updates are planned for this particular dataset, please visit the Global Partnership and Trust Fund Operations website for more details: http://go.worldbank.org/GABMG2YEI0

Indicates a legal status of the corresponding fund. ACTN = Active

view.name: IDA Statement Of Credits and Grants - Historical Data
view.description: The International Development Association (IDA) credits are public and publicly guaranteed debt extended by the World Bank Group. IDA provides development credits, grants and guarantees to its recipient member countries to help meet their development needs. Credits from IDA are at concessional rates. Data are in U.S. dollars calculated using historical rates. This dataset contains historical snapshots of the IDA Statement of Credits and Grants including the latest available snapshot. The World Bank complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions.

columns.name: End of Period
columns.description: End of Period Date represents the date when the snapshot was taken - ''as of" date for specific record.

columns.name: Credit Number
columns.description: For IBRD loans and IDA credits or grants a loan number consists of the organization prefix (IBRD/IDA) and a five-character label that uniquely identifies the loan within the organization.  In IDA, all grant labels start with the letter ‘H’.

columns.name: Region
columns.description: Country lending is grouped into regions based on the current World Bank administrative (rather than geographic) region where project implementation takes place. The Other Region is used for loans to the IFC.

columns.name: Country Code
columns.description: Country Code according to the World Bank country list. Might be different from the ISO country code.

columns.name: Country
columns.description: Country to which loan has been issued. Loans to the IFC are included under the country “World”.

columns.name: Borrower
columns.description: The representative of the borrower to which the Bank loan is made.

columns.name: Credit Status
columns.description: Status of the loan.See Data Dictionary attached in the About section or Data Dictionary dataset available from the list of all datasets for status descriptions.

columns.name: Service Charge Rate
columns.description: Current Interest rate or service charge applied to loan.  For loans that could have more than one interest rate (e.g. FSL or SCL fixed rate loans), the interest rate is shown as “0”.

columns.name: Currency of Commitment
columns.description: The currency in which a borrower’s loan, credit, grant or trust fund is denominated.

columns.name: Project ID
columns.description: A Bank project is referenced by a project ID (Pxxxxxxx).  More than one loan, credit, or grant may be associated with one Project ID.

columns.name: Project Name
columns.description: Short descriptive project name.

columns.name: Original Principal Amount
columns.description: The original US dollar amount of the loan that is committed and approved.

columns.name: Cancelled Amount
columns.description: The portion of the undisbursed balance which has been cancelled (i.e. no longer available for future disbursement).  Cancellations include terminations (where approved loan agreements were never signed).

columns.name: Undisbursed Amount
columns.description: The amount of a loan commitment that is still available to be drawn down. These currency amounts have been converted to US dollars at the exchange rates applicable at the end of period date.

columns.name: Disbursed Amount
columns.description: The amount that has been disbursed from a loan commitment in equivalent US dollars, calculated at the exchange rate on the value date of the individual disbursements.

columns.name: Repaid to IDA
columns.description: Total principal amounts paid or prepaid to IDA in US dollars, calculated at the exchange rate on the value date of the individual repayments. Repaid to IDA amounts include amounts written off under the Multilateral Debt Relief Initiative (MDRI).

columns.name: Due to IDA
columns.description: Amount due and outstanding as of the End of Period date.

columns.name: Exchange Adjustment
columns.description: The increase (decrease) in value of disbursed and outstanding amount due to exchange rate fluctuations.  This amount added to “Due to IBRD” yields “Borrower’s Obligation; includes exchange adjustments on the amounts Due to 3rd parties.

columns.name: Borrower's Obligation
columns.description:
The Borrower Obligation is the outstanding balance for the loan as of the end of period date in US dollars equivalent. 

The Borrower's Obligation includes the amounts outstanding Due to 3rd parties.

columns.name: Sold 3rd Party
columns.description: Portion of loan sold to a third party.

columns.name: Repaid 3rd Party
columns.description: Amount repaid to a third party.

columns.name: Due 3rd Party
columns.description: Amount due to a third party.

columns.name: Credits Held
columns.description: The sum of the disbursed and outstanding amounts (net of repayments, i.e.  Due to IBRD/IDA) plus undisbursed available amounts expressed in historical US Dollars.

columns.name: First Repayment Date
columns.description: The date on which principal repayment starts.

columns.name: Last Repayment Date
columns.description: The date specified in the loan/credit agreement (amended for any partial prepayments) on which the last principal installment must be repaid by the Borrower.

columns.name: Agreement Signing Date
columns.description: The date the borrower and the Bank sign the loan agreement.

columns.name: Board Approval Date
columns.description: The date the World Bank approves the loan.

columns.name: Effective Date (Most Recent)
columns.description: The date on which a legal agreement becomes effective, or is expected to become effective.

columns.name: Closed Date (Most Recent)
columns.description: The date specified in the legal agreement (or extension) after which the Bank may, by notice to the borrower, terminate the right to make withdrawals from the loan account.

columns.name: Last Disbursement Date
columns.description: The date on which the last disbursement was made (prior to the end of period date).

Additional Information.General Access Options: Query tool; API; Mobile App; Bulk download

view.name: Contributions to Financial Intermediary Funds
view.description:
Financial Intermediary Funds (FIFs) are multilateral financing arrangements for which the World Bank provides Trustee services that include committing and transferring funds to project       implementers (generally international organizations such as multilateral development banks or UN agencies).  In all cases the World Bank as Trustee is required to act in accordance with instructions of independent governing bodies.

In fulfilling its responsibilities, the World Bank as Trustee complies with all sanctions applicable to  World Bank transactions.


The innovative financing and governance arrangements of FIFs enable funds to be raised from multiple sources, including from sovereign and private sources. FIF structures are customizable. For instance FIFs have been customized to receive contributions in the form of concessional loans in addition to traditional grant funds, and can provide funding to recipients using customized financial products.

Data is provided as of 12/31/2013. No further updates are planned for this particular dataset.

view.name: Financial Intermediary Funds Funding Decisions
view.description:
Financial Intermediary Funds (FIFs) are multilateral financing arrangements for which the World Bank provides Trustee services that include committing and transferring funds to project implementers (generally international organizations such as multilateral development banks or UN agencies). In all cases the World Bank as Trustee is required to act in accordance with instructions of independent governing bodies.

In fulfilling its responsibilities, the World Bank as Trustee complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions.

Funding Decisions represent amounts approved by the FIFs governing bodies for projects fees and administrative budgets. Funding to projects can be done through various financial products, including grants and concessional loans.

No further updates are planned for this particular dataset.

columns.name: Source Code
columns.description: "1" is used for data from the national statistics office,  "2" for data from Central Bank, Banking Association, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Economy, or alike, "3" for data from Small Business Administration/Development/Promotion Agencies, SME Regional Institutions, SME Associations, etc. Also, Ministry of Industry or alike.

columns.name: GNI per Capita, Atlas Method
columns.description:
Data on GNI per capita, Atlas method, and total population come from the World Bank’s World Development Indicators (WDI) central database. Due to unavailability of the data from the WDI, the data from the United States Central Intelligence Agency Factbook are used in some cases. October 2013 ceilings for the classification of countries by income group using gross national income (GNI) per capita, Atlas method according to the World Bank List of Economies were used. However, the classification of each country corresponds to the year specified in the source for the data and definition. The historical income classification is based on the World Bank Analytical Classifications which provides information from 1987 to 2012.  

If the country observation line does not display information for the columns GNI per capita and population, it signals that the entry line provides only information about the MSME definition. This MSME definition has no data available in relation to it.

columns.name: Most widely used definition
columns.description:
The following steps were taken for selecting the MSME definition that seem to be used the most (Most widely used definition displays a value of 1 for each country. A value of zero is displayed otherwise):
- The definition is the only one found/available in that country.
- The definition has the most complete data associated to it.
- The data associated to the definition represent all (or more) economic sectors. 
- The definition and data come from a national institution.
- If at this point, there is still more than one definition, select the latest one (year).

columns.description: MSMEs2 attempts to capture all the available information regardless the existence of all the pieces (i.e., micro, small, medium or aggregates such as SMEs). For example, not only a country with micro and SME data contributes to MSME2 but also a country where only SME data is available contributes to MSME2 as well. It presents the number of enterprises for all the countries who have some information available. MSME presents information only when all the pieces of information are available, or when the information is directly provided for the total aggregate (total MSMEs).

cachedContents.largest: Value added figures are based on Eurostat data and definitions. The sector distributions are based on 2010 figures from Eurostat. Sector distribution, size breakdown, number of enterprises, and number of employees follow the format and definitions of Eurostat, it includes codes B to N and S95 according to NACE Rev.2.

top.item: Value added figures are based on Eurostat data and definitions. Sector distribution, size breakdown, number of enterprises, and number of employees follow the format and definitions of Eurostat, it includes codes B to N and S95 according to NACE Rev.2.
Contribution to GDP comes from TTCIC.
The number of employees in microenterprises include the self-employed (enterprises with zero employees).

Figures for 2010 were provided by OECD. The data cover the 'business economy' which includes industry, construction, trade, and services (NACE Rev. 1.1 Sections C to I, K). The data does not cover the nterprises in agriculture, forestry, fishing or the largely non-market services such as education and health. Value added figures are based on Eurostat data and definitions. Sector distribution, size breakdown, number of enterprises, and number of employees follow the format and definitions of Eurostat, it includes codes B to N and S95 according to NACE Rev.2.
The data for GNI per capita and population corresponds to the year 2013, obtained from IFC's Doing Business. There is no clear differentiation between microenterprises and SMEs.
The 2014 source comes from a UNIDO study published in 2012. Even though it is a recent publication, they are only able to provide a rough estimation.

2006 data includes agricultural sector. Data from the original focuses "mainly on businesses employing 5 or more persons with the exception of the following areas: Health and Social Work sector; Nursery Schools; Business Services including Legal Services, Accountancy Firms and other Consultancy Firms; Financial Intermediation and Insurance; Travel Agencies and Tour Operators; Radio Stations and Posts and Telecommunication and some Manufacturing businesses. The limitation to this was mainly due the limited finances available to undertake a complete registration".
The data excludes banks and budget organizations.

The classification of SMEs by number of employees was established for reporting purposes and utilizing the proposed cut-off from the original source (1-19 small, 20-499 medium, and >=500 large). This source presents the data in a detailed dissagregation level by enterprise size. Data provided is for businesses that have employees (i.e. businesses with zero employees are not included) according to the United States Census Bureau's methodology for data collection available at http://www.census.gov/econ/susb/methodology.html#universe

SBA has a detailed definition for MSMEs. Their data is presented based on number of employees for the following cases; nonemployers firms, firms with 1-19 employees, firms with 20-499 employees and firms with 500 employees or more.
The country does not define Medium Enterprises, rather the term Small is used for all categories related to entrepreneurship.

The country does not define Medium Enterprises, rather the term Small is used for all categories related to entrepreneurship. Data for population and GNI per capita correspond to the year 2012. Officials announced that in 2014 a report about Entrepreneurship in Uzbekistan will be issued. The sector breakdown is available from the the State Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan on Statistics at http://www.stat.uz/press/1/8359/?sphrase_id=108660

2008 data on GNI per Capita, Atlas Method are used for 2009. 2008 data on total population are used for 2009.  2007-2009 data covers only SME registered with the National Register of Contractors.  2007-2009 data does not cover cooperatives. There is no clear differentiation between microenterprises and SMEs.

GDP per capita (PPP) from CIA World Fact Book is used instead of GNI per capita. Data for the Economic Census of 2012 will be released in July 2014, see release schedule: http://www.census.gov/econ/islandareas/release_schedule.html

Results of the 2012 establishment census. The General Statistics Office of Vietnam also provides data for non-farm individual business establishments. The definition for non-farm individual business establishments states that those are firms "without establishment registration". Consequently, that information was not registered in the databse and it is presented here for informational purposes only. The reported number of non-farm individual firms is 5,162,419 and the number of workers in those firms is 7,946,699.
Several parameters for defining the formality of the non-farm individual business establishments do not allow to make a proper discrimination of formal and informal businesses. Even though the definition specifies that non-farm individual business establishments have no establishment rgistration, in the original document, it was stated that 31% of those establishments have “registered certificates” (p. 42). If registration is a parameter for formality, then, according to Table 43 of the original source document, only 41,128 establishments out of 5,162,419 have registered and no license (Table 20 states 5,162,419 is the total number of establishments for 2012, but table 43 has a different total number). Previously, it was stated that 31% of the establishments had “registered certificates”. Table 43 indicates the value of 30.9% as corresponding to “have a license” category. If this is the definition for formal, then, there will be 1,263,400 establishments that have a license.
2007 data include MSMEs in the private sector, non-governmental organization sector and government companies. 2013 data on GNI per Capita from IFC's Doing Business, is used for 2007.

The study "LITERATURE REVIEW ON SMALL AND MEDIUM ENTERPRISES’ ACCESS TO CREDIT AND SUPPORT IN SOUTH AFRICA, 2011" defines the value of contribution to GDP between 52 and 57%; however, their primary sources might date back to the beginnning of the decade of 2000. The rest of the information is provided by DTI.

view.name: Recipient-executed Grants -  Commitments and Disbursements
view.description:
A Recipient-executed Grant is a Trust Fund Grant that is provided to a third party under a grant agreement, and for which the Bank plays an operational role - i.e., the Bank normally appraises and supervises activities financed by these funds. This dataset provides data on the amount of grant funds committed in the course of a fiscal year and payments made out of a Trust Fund account to eligible recipients, in accordance with the legal agreements.  In fulfilling its responsibilities, the World Bank as Trustee complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions. All definitions should be regarded at present as provisional and not final, and are subject to revision at any time.

Data is provided at the individual Trust Fund level and is updated as of 03/14/2013. No further updates are planned for this particular dataset, please visit the Global Partnership and Trust Fund Operations website for more details: http://go.worldbank.org/GABMG2YEI0

view.name: Data Resources For Structural Economic Analysis
view.description: Collection of over 60 comprehensive international databases on the structure of the global economy, and standardized metadata for each, covering both technical characteristics of the data and detailed access information. Areas represented in the collection include output and value added by industrial sector, labor force, social and demographic data, productivity, and measures of economic endowments.

top.item: Timely Indicators of Entrepreneurship by Activity (ISIC4)

cachedContents.largest: Wikiprogress is a global platform for sharing information in order to evaluate societal progress. It is a place to find information and statistics to facilitate the exchange of ideas, initiatives and knowledge on “measuring the progress of societies”. It is open to all members and communities for contribution - students and researchers, civil society organisations, governmental and intergovernmental organisations, multilateral institutions, businesses, statistical offices, community organisations and individuals – anyone who has an interest in the concept of “progress”.

top.item: The GGDC Productivity Level database provides comparisons of output, inputs and productivity at a detailed industry level for a set of thirty OECD countries for 1997. It complements the EU KLEMS growth and productivity accounts by providing comparative levels and follows it in terms of country and industry coverage, variable definition and basic data.

The datahub on Comparative Historical National Accounts provides information on Gross Domestic Product at current and constant prices, including an industry breakdown for 10 major sectors, for the 19th and 20th centuries. This dataset is a complement to Angus Maddison’s estimates of World GDP. Currently it covers 21 countries in Asia, Europe and North America.
The Historical Statistics provide data on Population, GDP and GDP per capita for all countries in the world for the period 0-2008.

The Penn World Table (PWT) is a set of national-accounts data developed and maintained by scholars at the University of Pennsylvania to measure real GDP (per capita) from the corresponding relative price levels across countries and over time. The Penn World Table provides purchasing power parity and national income accounts converted to international prices for 189 countries/territories for some or all of the years 1950-2009. The European Union or the OECD provide more detailed purchasing power and real product estimates for their countries and the World Bank makes current price estimates for most PWT countries at the GDP level.
A panel dataset for cross-country analyses of national systems, growth and development (CANA) hosted by the Norwegian Institute of International Affairs.

The FAO Statistical Database (FAOSTAT) is an online multilingual database currently containing over one million time-series records from over 210 countries and territories covering statistics on agriculture, nutrition, fisheries, forestry, food aid, land use and population.

The AQUASTAT database provides information on water and agriculture by countries in the following main categories:
 -   Land use and population
 -   Climate and water resources
 -   Water use, by sector and by source
 -   Irrigation and drainage development
 -   Environment and health
 
AQUASTAT contains data on over 70 variables, searchable by country or by region per 5-year period.
Statistics and information on the worldwide supply, demand, and flow of minerals and materials. PDF files of annual country statistical reports for the years 1994-present can be downloaded.

Wikiprogress is a global platform for sharing information in order to evaluate societal progress. It is a place to find information and statistics to facilitate the exchange of ideas, initiatives and knowledge on “measuring the progress of societies”. It is open to all members and communities for contribution - students and researchers, civil society organisations, governmental and intergovernmental organisations, multilateral institutions, businesses, statistical offices, community organisations and individuals – anyone who has an interest in the concept of “progress”.

The SSI shows at a glance the level of sustainability and the distance to full sustainability of a country. The SSI is based on the well-known Brundtland definition and is built up by 24 indicators, comprises the three well-being dimensions of sustainability in its broad sense: human, environmental and economic well-being. It has been calculated for 151 countries.

The Barro-Lee Data set provides educational attainment data for 146 countries in 5-year intervals from 1950 to 2010. It also provides information about the distribution of educational attainment of the adult population over age 15 and over age 25 by sex at seven levels of schooling— no formal education, incomplete primary, complete primary, lower secondary, upper secondary, incomplete tertiary, and complete tertiary. Average years of schooling at all levels—primary, secondary, and tertiary—are also measured for each country and for regions in the world.

A historical database on educational attainment in 74 countries for the period 1870-2010, using perpetual inventory methods before 1960 and then the Cohen and Soto database. Authors use a measurement error framework to merge the two databases, while correcting for a systematic measurement bias in Cohen and Soto's study linked to differential mortality across educational groups.

Market Access Map covers customs tariffs (import duties) and other measures applied by 190 importing countries to products from 239 countries and territories. MFN and preferential applied import tariff rates are shown for products at the most detailed national tariff line level.

The International Financial Statistics database contains approximately 32,000 time-series covering more than 200 countries and regions. Includes all series appearing on the IFS country pages, exchange rates series for all Fund member countries, plus Anguilla, Aruba, China, P.R.: Hong Kong, China, P.R.: Macao, Montserrat, and the Netherlands Antilles, major Fund accounts series, real effective exchange rates, and other world, area, and country series from the world tables. Data are available for most IMF Member Countries with some aggregates calculated for select regions, plus some world totals.

CDIS is a worldwide statistical data collection effort led by the IMF designed to improve the availability and quality of data on direct investment, both overall and by immediate counterpart economy. The first CDIS was conducted as of end-year 2009, and it is being conducted annually thereafter. The concepts, coverage, valuation, and classification of data collected in the CDIS are consistent with the sixth edition of the Balance of Payments and International Investment Position Manual and the fourth edition of the OECD Benchmark Definition of Foreign Direct Investment. The results from the CDIS include data and metadata reported by individual economies, as well as interactively generated metadata tables for any or all individual economies.

(GFSM 2001), an internationally recognized statistical reporting framework, is aimed at helping national authorities to strengthen their capacity to formulate fiscal policy and monitor fiscal developments. The GFSM 2001 supports the balance sheet approach to analyzing economic policy by bringing together stocks and flows in a transparent and consistent framework.

Since its first edition in 1935-36, the Yearbook of Labour Statistics has become established as the world’s foremost work of statistical reference on labour questions, bringing together in systematic form a wealth of data from a vast network of authoritative sources of information in nearly countries, areas and territories. The statistics are published, wherever possible, according to the latest versions of the following international standard classifications: International Standard Industrial Classification of all Economic Activities (ISIC-Rev. 3); International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-88); International Classification of Status in Employment (ICSE-93) and the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED-97).

The concepts and definitions of household income, household expenditure and household consumption expenditure preferred as standards of reference for the completion of this questionnaire are those contained in the resolution concerning household income and expenditure statistics, adopted by the Seventeenth International Conference of Labour Statisticians, December 2003.

Data on births and deaths of enterprises, their life expectancy and the important role they play in economic growth and productivity, as well as the information they provide for tackling social demographic issues are increasingly requested by policy makers and analysts alike. The cooperation with national statistical offices has resulted in the collection of high quality data (See official SDBS data obtained using a questionnaire), but sometimes at the expense of timeliness. Following the economic crisis, many requests for more recent empirical evidence were received. Consequently, the OECD has created a new dataset on timely indicators. Monthly and/or quarterly information are now available on line.

The UIS collects S&T data from more than 200 countries and territories through its biennial research and experimental development survey and partnerships with other statistical organizations.  The aim is to build a comprehensive global database that covers a range of internationally comparable science indicators, such as R&D expenditure, R&D personnel and gender disparities in diverse fields of science. The data provide a global perspective that is relevant to policymakers on the state of science and research infrastructure.

Wealth estimates are calculated for 3 years—1995, 2000 and 2005. Adjusted Net Saving and non-renewable resource rent indicators are calculated annually from 1970 to 2008.

The share of each component of GDP/VA is derived on the basis of current price series in national currency. For further information on countries' notes on GDP/VA breakdown, please see: http://unstats.un.org/unsd/snaama/downloads/Download-GDPcurrent-USD-countries.xls.
Data gaps for some countries and years. Generally at ISIC Division level. Data Availability and Country List: http://unstats.un.org/unsd/snaama/cList.asp

This database contains national accounts statistics compiled according to 1993 SNA or 1968 SNA methodology. It is based on the UN National Accounts Questionnaire (NAQ). The structure of and the classifications used in the NAQ are based on the 1993 SNA. As far as possible, data from the historical database were converted and uploaded into the 1993 SNA structure. For the main aggregates, the 1993 SNA database contains recalculated data starting as early as 1946. The database is continuously developed further.

Data are collected from the national statistical offices (NSOs) except for OECD member countries. Data gaps for some countries and years. Data Availability and Country List: http://www.unido.org/Data1/Statistics/Databases/ISAV.cfm?dig=4

Data are collected from the national statistical offices (NSOs) except for OECD member countries. Data gaps for some countries and years. Data Availability and Country List: http://www.unido.org/Data1/Statistics/Databases/ISAV.cfm?dig=2

Coverage in terms of years, as well as data items, varies from country to country depending on data availability. As of 2010, UNIDO has discontinued the compilation of Industrial Demand-Supply Balance Database (IDSB) at the 4-digit level of ISIC Revision 2.
The country data are given in comparison with figures for the geographical region or development group it belongs to.
Annual data is available on aggregate growth of output and input as well as productivity levels and growth for some 112 countries, for the period 1960-2000.

The CIPI includes the following six crucial variables of industrial development:
-Manufacturing Value Added (MVA) per capita (MVApc)
-Manufactured Exports per capita (MXpc)
-Share of MVA in GDP (MVAsh)
-Share of Medium- and High-tech (MHT) Value Added in total Manufacturing Value Added
(MHVAsh)
-Share of Manufactured Exports in total Merchandised Exports (MXsh)
-Share of Medium- and High-tech Exports in manufactured exports (MHXsh)

The OECD R&D and GBAORD Sources and Methods databases contain metadata, relating to the series presented in Main Science and Technology Indicators and Research and Development Statistics and are available at: http://webnet.oecd.org/rd_gbaord_metadata/default.aspx

1.-Unless otherwise noted, total merchandise trade is defined according to the general trade definition. Under the general trade system the statistical territory of a country coincides with its economic territory and includes customs warehouses and free zones.
-Unless otherwise stated, the valuation of exports is f.o.b. (free on board) and that of imports is c.i.f. (cost insurance freight).
-Variances of total trade figures between Total Merchandise Trade and Merchandise Trade Matrix Tables are to be expected due to differences in principal data sources.
2. Annual average growth rates are defined as the coefficient b in the exponential trend function y = ae^bt  where t stands for time. Since all observations in a period are taken into account, the resulting growth rates reflect trends that are not unduly influenced by exceptional values.
3. For countries which report their imports on the f.o.b. basis, the trade balance is also shown on the f.o.b. basis. The regional trade balances are the sums of the reported trade balances for the relevant individual countries. A negative sign indicates a trade deficit.
4. Whenever possible, volume indices are compiled directly from various publications reported by national or international sources; otherwise they are derived from the calculations based on trade values and unit value indices or price indices. Due to limited publicly available data, country groups shown in this table are calculated based on the total of 57 countries representing around 92.5% of world trade. To ensure diverse representation, each of the country groups is represented by at least two individual major trading countries. Only individual economies for which volume indices were reported are shown in detail.

The principal data source is UN DESA Statistics Division, UN COMTRADE which provides detailed raw trade data by partner and product. The source figures may be adjusted or complemented, when considered necessary.  Figures are estimated whenever possible to fill in the gaps in the absence of official data. The adjusted data or estimates are marked to differentiate them from the original data.
To the extent possible, the attempt was made to distribute the reported figures for unknown partners or products to estimated partners or products. As a consequence, this matrix does not include unknown partners or products (SITC, Rev.3 code 93 and 931). In addition, the sum of individual partners and the sum of individual products for a reporter may not add-up to its (total) trade to the world and its (total) trade of all products, respectively.
Total trade figures in UNCTADstat Merchandise Trade Matrix may differ from UNCTADstat Total Merchandise Trade due to data discrepancies between their principal data sources.

1. The value index is the current value of exports (f.o.b.) or imports (c.i.f.) converted to U.S. dollars and expressed as a percentage of the average of the base period (2000). The volume index is the percentage ratio of the export or import value index to the corresponding unit value index. The terms of trade or "net barter" terms of trade is the percentage ratio of the export unit value index to the import unit value index. The purchasing power index of exports is the value index of exports deflated by the import unit value index.
Due to lack of data publicly available, no estimation is attempted for non-reported indices of individual countries before year 2000. As consequence, indices at the level of geographical regions and economic groupings are not calculated in those time periods.
2. Number of products is based on SITC, Revision 3 commodity classification at 3-digit group level. This figure includes only those products that are greater than 100,000 dollars or more than 0.3 per cent of the country’s or country group’s total exports or imports. The maximum number of products is 261.
Diversification index that ranges from 0 to 1 reveals the extent of the differences between the structure of trade of the country or country group and the world average. The index value closer to 1 indicates a bigger difference from the world average. Diversification index is computed by measuring absolute deviation of the country share from world structure
Concentration index, also named Herfindahl-Hirschmann index, is a measure of the degree of market concentration. It has been normalized to obtain values ranking from 0 to 1. An index value that is close to 1 indicates a very concentrated market (maximum concentration). On the contrary, values closer to 0 reflect a more equal distribution of market shares among exporters or importers.
3. Concentration index, also named Herfindahl-Hirschmann index, is a measure of the degree of market concentration. It has been normalized to obtain values ranking from 0 to 1. An index value that is close to 1 indicates a very concentrated market (maximum concentration). On the contrary, values closer to 0 reflect a more equal distribution of market shares among exporters or importers.
Structural change index, ranging from 0 to 1 reveals the structural change in trade for a particular product as compared to the reference year (1995 = 0). An index value close to 1 indicates a significant change in the composition of exporters (importers).  On the contrary, values closer to 0 would demonstrate a higher degree of traditionality in the markets over the period concerned.

Average tariff of a market country for an origin group (except for world) is calculated by taking those products (at HS 6-digit level) that are imported by the market country from each country included in the origin group. i.e., tariff rates for those products that are not traded are not included in the calculation. For world as origin, however, all products are taken into consideration regardless of trade.

1. Foreign direct investment (FDI) is defined as an investment involving a long-term relationship and reflecting a lasting interest in and control by a resident entity in one economy (foreign direct investor or parent enterprise) of an enterprise resident in a different economy (FDI enterprise or affiliate enterprise or foreign affiliate). Such investment involves both the initial transaction between the two entities and all subsequent transactions between them and among foreign affiliates.
FDI inflows and outflows comprise capital provided (either directly or through other related enterprises) by a foreign direct investor to a FDI enterprise, or capital received by a foreign direct investor from a FDI enterprise. FDI includes the three following components: equity capital, reinvested earnings and intra-company loans. Data on FDI flows are presented on net bases (capital transactions' credits less debits between direct investors and their foreign affiliates). Net decreases in assets or net increases in liabilities are recorded as credits, while net increases in assets or net decreases in liabilities are recorded as debits. Hence, FDI flows with a negative sign indicate that at least one of the three components of FDI is negative and not offset by positive amounts of the remaining components. These are called reverse investment or disinvestment.
2. Foreign direct investment (FDI) is defined as an investment involving a long-term relationship and reflecting a lasting interest in and control by a resident entity in one economy (foreign direct investor or parent enterprise) of an enterprise resident in a different economy (FDI enterprise or affiliate enterprise or foreign affiliate).  Such investment involves both the initial transaction between the two entities and all subsequent transactions between them and among foreign affiliates.
FDI stock is the value of the share of their capital and reserves (including retained profits) attributable to the parent enterprise, plus the net indebtedness of affiliates to the parent enterprises.

3. The calculation of concentration index is based on normalized Herfindahl-Hirschmann index.

Creative services international trade data are presented and analyzed in UNCTAD's Creative Economy Report. The value of total exports and imports of creative services is inevitably underestimated, as all the statistical detail necessary is rarely systematically reported. What countries report at the moment that was identified as covering creative services, but not exclusively, is the following categories of services: (1) advertising, market research and public opinion polling services, (2) architectural, engineering and other technical, (3) research and development services, (4) personal, cultural and recreational services, (5) audiovisual and related services, and (6) other other personal, cultural and recreational services.
For more information, please see the explanatory notes from the Creative Economy Report 2010 - Statistical Annex (http://unctadstat.unctad.org/UnctadStatMetadata/Documentation/CER2010_StatAnnex.pdf)

For project information IFC discloses on a daily basis, please refer to the IFC Disclosure Portal: http://www.ifc.org/disclosure

view.name: World Bank Morocco Citizen Engagement Nano-Survey (Access to Information & Right to Petition/Motion)
view.description: This dataset contains raw response data to a nano-survey that was conducted in Morocco on the right to access to information and the right to petition and motion the government. A nano-survey is an innovative technology that extends a brief survey to a random sampling of internet users. Note: "NA" or "N/A" indicates "No Answer." Sub-national location data is available for 2/3 of survey recipients. 54,441 random internet users in Morocco were exposed to a portion of this survey, with 15,020 respondents providing at least partial responses.

view.name: Financial Intermediary Funds Cash Transfers
view.description:
Financial Intermediary Funds (FIFs) are multilateral financing arrangements for which the World Bank provides Trustee services that include committing and transferring funds to project implementers (generally international organizations such as multilateral development banks or UN agencies).

In all cases the World Bank as Trustee is required to act in accordance with instructions of independent governing bodies. In fulfilling its responsibilities, the World Bank as Trustee complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions.

This dataset provides data on FIFs cash transfers at the transaction detail level. Funds are channeled in a coordinated manner to a range of recipients in the public and private sectors through a variety of arrangements. FIF trusteeship involves holding, investing and transferring funds as directed by the FIF governing body. Trusteeship does not involve overseeing or supervising the use of funds; this is the role of other agencies that receive the funding and who are responsible for project or program implementation. Transfers are generally made by the Trustee to external agencies (other MDBs, UN agencies, etc.) for the implementation of activities.

Data is updated as of 12/31/2013. No further updates are planned for this particular dataset.

view.name: Pipeline research – open data driven companies in emerging markets
view.description: This dataset contains the names and basic information about companies that were contacted in the process of a research which aimed to identify open data companies in emerging markets, specifically in Latin America, Southeast Asia, Africa, as well as India and Russia.  The data was collected by several vendors and consultants and was not validated independently by the World Bank staff.  Data was collected over a short period of 4-6 weeks in the spring of 2014 and represents data-centric companies that vendors/consultants were able to identify in that timeframe.

view.name: Total Contributions to IBRD/IDA/IFC Trust Funds - Summary based on FY of Agreement
view.description:
A Trust Fund is a financing arrangement set up with contributions from one or more donor(s), and in some
cases from the World Bank Group. A Trust Fund can be country-specific, regional, or global in its
geographic scope, and it can be free-standing or programmatic.  In fulfilling its responsibilities, the World Bank as Trustee complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions. This dataset  provides a summary of the contributions per fiscal year at the individual Trust Fund level. All definitions should be regarded at present as provisional and not final, and are subject to revision at any time. Please refer to http://www.cfpto.org/TFGlossary2012/ for the Trust Fund Glossary.

Data is updated as of 09/12/2012. No further updates are planned for this particular dataset.

view.name: 2017 Climate Investment Funds – Clean Technology Fund (CTF) results data
view.description:
The results data presented below is based on the portfolio of CTF projects and has been compiled on behalf of the following multilateral development banks: ADB, AFDB, EBRD, IDB, IFC and IBRD. It follows the principles outlined under the Revised CTF Results Framework and includes five core indicators that help determine whether and to what extent the CTF interventions achieve the proposed project/ program outcome objectives involving:
(a) Avoided greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions; (b) Increased finance for low carbon development mobilized; (c) Increased supply of renewable energy (RE); (d) Increased access to public transport; (e) Increased energy efficiency.

Please note that this is based on 53 out of 55 projects reporting results and does not include (2) CONFIDENTIAL projects. You can learn more about specific indicators at https://www.climateinvestmentfunds.org/cif/sites/climateinvestmentfunds.org/files/CTF%20Monitoring%20and%20Reporting%20Toolkit%20Version%204.6%20.pdf .

view.name: Financial Intermediary Funds Commitments
view.description:
Financial Intermediary Funds (FIFs) are multilateral financing arrangements for which the World Bank provides Trustee services that include committing and transferring funds to project implementers (generally international organizations such as multilateral development banks or UN agencies).

In all cases the World Bank as Trustee is required to act in accordance with instructions of independent governing bodies. In fulfilling its responsibilities, the World Bank as Trustee complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions.

This dataset provides data on legal obligations to pay recipients of FIFs. Data is updated as of 12/31/2013. No further updates are planned for this particular dataset please visit: http://fiftrustee.worldbank.org

cachedContents.largest: With MapStory, we provide a lay-accessible platform for sharing and editing open spatio-temporal data and using it to compose spatial narratives about how places change over time (MapStories). As an open data platform, MapStory helps advance civic participation and public education and makes it easier to use data for a variety of real-world development projects. It operates world-wide and is agnostic as to the subject matter focus of the data.

Premise uses a combination of open data and self-collected data.

The project aims to visualize Brazil's federal budget in a more friendly way. It is a tool which synthesizes information, updated monthly, about the financial spending of all federal government agencies, enabling the monitoring of the performance of these agencies throughout the year, as well as comparisons between the resources available for each government area.

Panjiva is a search engine for products, suppliers and services- exploring how startups are using datasets in creative problem-solving. Using government data to build a platform for international trade, Panjiva helps users map relationships between buyers and suppliers. Panjiva expands on U.S. government data to increase the value of its six-million company database. Organizing shipping data, from U.S. Customs records, and partnering operational and financial data with subjective data provides users with essential insights in selecting international service providers. This has led to a continually growing estimated 188,800, 000,000 dollar value of purchased goods.

Gobierno Local es un portal del Ministerio del Interior y Transporte de la Nación, construido de forma colaborativa, que tiene como objetivo principal contribuir a la promoción y desarrollo de los municipios de Argentina. Se trata de un proyecto que forma parte del Programa de Mejora de la Gestión Municipal (PMGM) alojado en la UEC – Unidad Ejecutora Central de este Ministerio (Préstamo BID 1855/OC-AR). 

En materia de utilización de Open Data para el desarrollo, Gobierno Local brinda información y servicios basados en la gestión colaborativa del conocimiento y en la reutilización de datos públicos y abiertos, por medio de la implementación de un Atlas municipal con información disponible basada en indicadores de los censos 2001 y 2010 de la República Argentina. Asimismo, se propone incluir información suministrada por los propios municipios para su reutilización y comparación. Se espera que los datos estén georreferenciados.

Tiene previstas distintas fuentes: 
- Organismos de Estadísticas (Nacionales como el Instituto Nacional de Estadísticas y Censos, provinciales y -de ser posible- municipal). 
- Organismos nacionales con información a nivel local (ministerio de Salud, de Educación, etc.) 
- Municipalidades y Comunas. 
- Espera vincularse asimismo con el Portal de Datos Públicos de la República Argentina.

This indicator measures the total area of land provided with irrigation and drainage services under the financed projects, including in (i) the area provided with new irrigation and drainage services, and (ii) the area provided with improved irrigation and drainage services, expressed in hectare (ha).

PI-21 in PEFA covers Effectiveness of Internal Audit—Regular and adequate feedback to management is required on the performance of the internal control systems, through an internal audit function. Such a function should meet international standards such as ISPPIA (International Standards for the Professional Practice in Internal Audit, issued by Institute of Internal Auditors). The internal audit function may be undertaken by an organization with a mandate across entities of the central government of by separate internal audit functions for individual government entities. The combined effectiveness of all such audit organizations is the basis for this indicator. This indicator is scored against 3 dimensions - coverage and quality of internal audit function, frequency and distribution of reports, and extent of management response to internal audit findings.
PI 26 and 28 covers scope/nature/follow up of external audit and legislative scrutiny of external audit reports respectively—A high quality external audit is an essential requirement for creating transparency in the use of public funds. Key elements of the quality of actual external audit comprise the scope/ coverage of the audit, adherence to appropriate auditing standards including independence of the external audit institution, focus on significant systemic PFM issues in its reports, and performance of the full range of financial audit. PI 26 is scored against 3 dimensions - scope/ nature of audit performed, timeliness of submission of audit reports to legislature, and evidence of follow up on audit recommendations.
The legislature has a key role in exercising scrutiny over the execution of the budget that is approved. The common way this is done is through a legislative committee that examines the external audit reports and questions responsible parties about the findings of the reports. This indicator is scored against 3 dimensions - timeliness of examination of audit reports by the legislature, extent of hearings on key findings undertaken by the legislature, and issuance of recommended actions by the legislature and implementation by the executive.

view.name: IFC Advisory Services Projects
view.description:
Private sector development requires more than just finance. Experience shows the powerful role advisory services can play in unlocking investment and helping businesses expand and create jobs.

To help the private sector in emerging markets, IFC provides advice, problem solving, and training to companies, industries, and governments. Our experience shows that companies need more than financial investment to thrive—they need a regulatory environment that enables entrepreneurship, and advice on business best practices. Our work includes advising national and local governments on how to improve their investment climate and strengthen basic infrastructure. Governments account for around half of our advisory projects. We also help investment clients improve corporate governance and become more sustainable.

For project information IFC discloses on a daily basis, please refer to the IFC Disclosure Portal: http://www.ifc.org/disclosure

columns.name: Agribusiness and Forestry
columns.description: In millions of USD, Agribusiness plays a vital role in economic development. In countries with low per capita incomes, the agricultural sector often accounts for half or more of the gross domestic product and 60-80 percent of total employment.

columns.name: Telecommunications and Information Technologies
columns.description: In millions of USD. IFC investment in this sector adds value to clients in the telecoms, media and technology sectors through private sector financing and advisory services.  Access to these services is fundamental to expanding the reach of development.

columns.name: Manufacturing
columns.description: In millions of USD. IFC focuses on key industries that form the foundation of sustainable growth and that provide affordable goods and services to consumers, create jobs, contribute to government revenue, and stimulate local small and medium enterprises.

columns.name: Infrastructure
columns.description: In millions of USD. IFC is scaling up infrastructure investments that have the most impact in low-income developing countries. We are continuing our work in early stage project development, and expanding our investments in harder sectors such as water.

columns.name: Oil, Gas & Mining
columns.description: In millions of USD. Natural resource industries are important for many of the world's poorest countries: they are a key source of jobs, economic opportunities, investments, revenues to government, energy and other benefits for local economies.

columns.name: Consumer & Social Services
columns.description: In millions of USD. Private health care and education are fundamental to human and economic development—health care plays a key role in improving the quality of life, while education is a powerful instrument for reducing poverty and growing human capital.

columns.name: Financial Markets
columns.description: In millions of USD. IFC’s Financial Markets department accounts for almost half of IFC’s new investments each year. We focus on small and medium enterprises, microfinance, climate change, and agri-finance.

view.name: IBRD/IDA/IFC Trust Funds - Annual Cash Contributions and Disbursements
view.description:
For IBRD/IDA and IFC Trust Funds, the World Bank Group is normally responsible for all financial and programmatic functions, including oversight of the operational use of the funding.  In fulfilling its responsibilities, the World Bank as Trustee complies with all sanctions applicable to World Bank transactions. The use of IBRD/IDA TFs is split between Bank-executed trust funds (BETFs), which are used in support of the Bank's work program, and Recipient-executed trust funds (RETFs), under which funds are provided to a third party, normally in the form of project financing, and supervised by the Bank. IFC manages the funds in support of IFC advisory services and donor-funded investments.

No further updates are planned for this particular dataset, please visit the Global Partnership and Trust Fund Operations website for more details: http://go.worldbank.org/GABMG2YEI0

view.name: LCR South South Knowledge Exchange Activities
view.description: Knowledge exchange involves activities connecting policy makers and development practitioners within and cross countries to learn from each other`s experiences for the purpose of identifying, customizing, replicating, and/or scaling up workable development solutions and policies. These activities can include workshops, dialogues, expert visits, peer consultations, study tours, and twinning arrangements

The second objective was to identify relevant action lines to improve current national programs to foster business linkages more effectively, accelerate domestic firmsâ productivity competences and upgrading, and thereby increase Costa Rican SMEâs participation in global value chains. top.item:
This exchange will be designed as a 7-9-day study tour to Peru and a series of follow-up video 
conferences. The study tour will start in Lima, the capital of Peru, and will continue in three different 
provinces: Pucallpa and Tingo MarÃa in the Amazon rainforest, and HuÃ¡nuco in the highlands. In each province, the study tour will include a mixed two-day program, consisting of presentations and site visit demonstrations; involving MOTC, PVD, PRIs, microenterprises, University of HuÃ¡nuco, and discussions with community members and other road users. For learning purposes, the knowledge providing organizations will share both successful and unsuccessful experience. The knowledge exchange program will include the following presentations: organizational modality of a microenterprise / maintenance association (including legal status of a microenterprise), maintenance contracts (contract types, forms, values, obligations, financing (including remuneration and flow of funds), and penalties); training of staff and supervisors, management of works (road inventory, timing and frequency of activities, reporting and supervision of works), role of the Road Authority / Local Government and interactions with the microenterprises, implications on on-going maintenance contracts with government owned or privately owned maintenance companies if any, and key lessons learnt by the stakeholders involved in the process. A series of follow-up video conferences will be arranged by the Bank between the Peruvian and Armenian development practitioners once the Armenian counterparts start the design and/or the implementation and have more specific hands-on questions. The follow up activities beyond the exchange in the Peru will be financed through the loan proceeds of the LRNIP project within the subcomponent âPilot for routine maintenance through Microenterprisesâ to ensure sustainability and complementarity to the knowledge exchange program by adapting gained knowledge to the local context.

A delegation from the Government of Colombia will visit Lima, Peru, to participate in a knowledge exchange with the Ministry of Economy and Finance, the Supreme Audit Institution and other public institutions. The goal is to learn about the Peruvian experience in implementing the accounting reforms and regulations in adopting international accounting and financial reporting standards, given Colombia's current accounting reforms and timetable to implement such reforms.

On 23-24 April 2013, Mr Miguel Arestegui (Coordinator of the NGO Soluciones Practicas in Peru) has been invited by the Haiti Minister of Energy Security to speak at the Haiti second Rural Electrification workshop. This Bank funded event (SFLAC TF, P125916) aimed to present the feedback and perspectives of the on-going GoH program on rural electrification.
To this extent, M. Arestegui presented various examples of value added in rural productive activities thanks to an adequate supply of energy. In Particular, he presented the lessons learned from the Bank funded Peru Rural Electrification project (P090116), of which Soluciones Practicas was a partner.
During the same event, Koffi Ekouevi also presented the lessons learned from the Bank funded rural electrification projects in Bangladesh (P131263 ) and Mali (P073036).

There will be two separate activities in this knowledge exchange: 1. Study Tour: The delegation of UB City will visit knowledge providersâ cities and exchange their experience and knowledge directly with government officials, technical staff and rating agencies that are involved in the credit rating experience and in bond issuance. The delegation will also visit local banks that purchased bonds, the Ministry of Finance and the Central Bank that oversees the bond issuance. 2. Back-to-Office Workshop: Upon return, will also participate in a workshop to share their knowledge with other government officials, particularly with the Mayor and other members of the Treasury Department. In the workshop, a draft action plan towards creditworthiness assessment will be shared and discussed with the audience.
Eight-month consulting engagement to advise the Government of Colombia on travel demand management skills with support of IE Singapore.

The main objective of the mission was to learn more about the management model and systems in place used by the subnational governments; its design, institutional arrangements and implementation mechanisms. For that purpose, a number of visits were scheduled with the public entities in charge of the management system and with different municipalities. The study tour was carried out in the context of the Subnational Institutional Strengthening Project with the Colombian Government (P123879) and the SIDAFF Fee-based Service with SHCP (P132084) in Mexico. Government officials from Colombiaâs Planning National Department (DNP) and Fiscal Support Directorate from the Ministry of Finance (DAF), as well as Mexicoâs Ministry of Finance Accounting Unit (UCGIGP) participated in all the meetings.

WB team promoted the participation of one representative of the Brazilian Ministry of Labor in a study tour to Australia organized by MENA-HD focused on themes relevant to our counterparts: (i) monitoring and evaluation system, (ii) public-private partnership system to deliver public employment services; (iii) private provision in remote parts of the country where capacity of providers is more limited.

Obras Sanitarias del Estado (OSE), the Uruguayan Water utility organized, on April 8 - 9 2013, a workshop on Risk Management in water utilities. The workshop aimed to help OSE in its strategic analysis of how to integrate risk management in company-wide planning, one of the goals of the OSE Sustainable and Efficient Project.

The contribution of Mexico, namely INEGI, to the Census in Bolivia has been substantial.  Census experts from INEGI participated in various missions and activities to provide valuable technical support to INE in Bolivia.  This has included the review of the census questionnaire, operational plans, training plans, etc.  In addition, a representative of INEGI participated as an international observer of the Population Census in November 2012.

the Bank conducted analytical work comparing the national drought policies of five countries (Mexico, Brazil, Spain, Australia, USA) to support Brazil's endeavor to elaborate its first national drought policy. This work fed into a discussion among Mexico, Brazil and Jordan at a high-level international meeting in Geneva on national drought policies, and raised the interest from MENA colleagues (incl. to share findings with Djibouti government). Follow-up exchanges on drought policies are foreseen between Brazil and Mozambique in the context of our forthcoming ESW.

The two proposed Capacity Outcomes (Raised Awareness, and Improved Consensus) were satisfactorily achieved with the visits to Indonesia, Mexico and Chile. Senior policy makers and policy advisors from various line ministries and academic institutions were impressed with what they have learnt from discussions with relevant counterparts in the knowledge providing countries, and a BTOR report was prepared for the cabinet. Highlighted lessons cover the following areas (i) Public debt management in Mexico, (ii) Public Investment Management in Chile; (iii) Banking and SOE reform in Indonesia since the crisis 97-98.
The SSKE comprised 3 outputs: a study of the Colombian case, a study of the Mexican case and a synthesis report including key lessons (being finalized).

The different models presented during the exchange proved valuable for the participants, mainly mayors of Oaxaca. They proposed the creation of a Knowledge Community to continue sharing their experiences for inter-municipal management for the reduction of poverty.

The discussion on infrastructure development and wastewater operations in Managua helped officials in Ho Chi Minh City to take informed decisions on drainage, sewage, and wastewater management as the city gets ready to ramp up activities in these areas to see the wastewater treatment plant which has a PPP arrangement and a where a low cost treatment technology is being used.

On January 23, 2012, President Martelly (President of Haiti) attended the SFLAC funded workshop and announced a Government supported 2 year program on rural electrification, named 'Bam Limiye, Bam Lavi' (BLBL, 'give me light, give me life'): $30m to provide electricity access to 200,000 new households in rural areas, plus $10m for solar street lighting on 375 km of rural roads.

Panama rolled out an innovative approach for the delivery of health services using mobile health teams which brings health services to the rural communities instead of them having to travel far to access health care.

The Grant contributed to strengthening the Caribbean capacity to respond to protect nutritional status of mothers and children in times of crises and emergencies by developing a long-standing, self-paced online course customized to the Caribbean context which addresses non communicable diseases (NCDs).

As a result of the visit, it was agreed that on of Oxacaâs health care centers offered training on maternal and neonatal health. The leading doctor of the institution was invited to speak at the âEncuentro Nacional del PerÃº sobre atenciÃ³n intercultural del parto y nacimientoâ.
Haiti Ministry for Energy Security decided to add to its rural electrification program a component on energy for productive uses in rural areas.

Representatives of the IE Singapore traveled 3 times to Bogota, where they met with authorities from the city and the Ministry of Transport. As a result of the dialogue, IE Singapore produced a report on the feasibility of a congestion charging scheme based on the case of Bogota and including guidelines for cities willing to adopt the system.

The overall BiscayTIK experience and approach is highly relevant to most LAC countries. Specifically, the main common problems and issues include (i) how to best manage small, rural and low capacity municipalities, (ii) how to provide public services to citizens, (iii) the importance of a detailed analysis of the institutional arrangements, (iv) incentives for having the municipalities onboard, and (v) specific mechanisms for the systemsâ implementation and sustained mass capacity building. The Government officials were positively impressed with the management model and were convinced that even though each management system needs to be applied to the local circumstances and context, the overall philosophy and many elements of the institutional arrangements could inspire the new sub-national management strengthening approach and implementation.

At the request of Brazil's Min of Envt, the Bank in Brasilia facilitated knowledge exchange between Mozambique and Brazil on how to lead a national and multi-sector process of elaborating national plans of adaptation to CC. Mozambique shared its experience since 2005 and its lessons learned from its Pilot Program for Climate Resilience (PPCR) which were greatly appreciated by Brazil, which is embarking on this process only now. This was done through a VC with GoM and GoB. Follow-up BBLs are foreseen with Govts of Zambia and Bolivia (also PPCR pilot countries) before the end of the FY.

view.name: IFC Subscriptions and Voting Power of Member Countries
view.description:
Member countries are allocated votes at the time of membership and subsequently for additional subscriptions to capital. Votes are allocated differently in each organization.

Each member receives votes consisting of share votes (one vote for each share of IFC's capital stock held by the member) plus basic votes (calculated so that the sum of all basic votes is equal to 5.55 percent of the sum of basic votes and share votes for all members).

Latest information about voting power is available at http://www.worldbank.org/en/about/leadership/votingpowers

view.name: Education  - Education Implementation Completion Reports
view.description:
The World Bank prepares an Implementation Completion Report (ICR) for each lending operation it finances. It assesses (a) the degree to which the project achieved its development objective and outputs as set out in the project documents; (b) other significant outcomes and impacts; (c) prospects for the project's sustainability; and (d) Bank and borrower performance, including compliance with relevant Bank safeguard and business policies.  It also provides the data and analysis to substantiate these assessments, and it identifies the lessons learned from implementation. The borrower prepares and provides to the Bank its own evaluation report on the project's execution and initial operation, its cost and the benefits to be derived from it, the Bank's and borrower's performance of their obligations under the Loan Agreement, and the extent to which the purposes of the loan were achieved.  The borrower's summary of this report (or the full report, if it is 10 pages or fewer) is attached unedited to the ICR.  The borrower also assists the Bank in the preparation of the ICR. An ICR is not prepared for a loan that fails to become effective or is canceled before significant implementation is initiated.  Instead, a Project Completion Note to the Board summarizes the project and explains why it was not implemented.

Below is a list of education ICRs (FY13 on wards), along with an abstract of their key findings and a link to the available full text ICR documents.  The project portal contains additional project information and is also provided.  If you have any questions about these reports, please contact the Education Advisory Service (eservice@worldbank.org).
